text: So we've seen how ME can mean ME, TO ME or MYSELF and TE can mean YOU, TO YOU or YOURSELF and NOS can mean US, TO US or OURSELVES.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we want to resist the temptation to translate this TO.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So for example, HE SPEAKS TO ME.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We don't need this TO because ME, ME, can mean ME, TO ME or MYSELF.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we want to resist the temptation to translate that TO.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how do you say HE SPEAKS TO ME or HE'S SPEAKING TO ME?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Yeah, don't let that TO confuse you about the position it should go.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Good, if you want to say THEY SPEAK TO ME ABOUT IT, you can just say THEY SPEAK ME IT in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Very good, THEY'RE SPEAKING TO ME ABOUT IT.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this TO and this ABOUT, we notice Spanish tends not to need these words as much as English does.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, TO BUY was COMPRAR.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Good, so this ME other than TO ME can be FOR ME, FROM ME.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We don't really need these words.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So for example, if you want to say HE BUYS IT FOR ME, we can just say HE BUYS ME IT.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So here we see ME is like FOR ME here, but it's just ME.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I BUY IT FOR YOU, speaking informally.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, if you want to say SHALL I BUY IT FOR YOU, SHALL in English, all it's doing really is just making it a question.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: SHALL I BUY IT FOR YOU?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So in Spanish, just make it sound like a question.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: SHALL I BUY IT FOR YOU?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, this could actually even mean FROM YOU.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: SHALL I BUY IT FROM YOU?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So by the context, we'll understand the difference.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Maybe you will hear if you travel to a Spanish-speaking country, people saying BUY ME, selling things in the street.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: BUY ME SOMETHING is what you will hear.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And they're probably not asking you to buy them something, but to buy something from them.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And it's understood, and we don't really need to use these words like FROM or FOR most of the time.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say, DO YOU WANT TO DO?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: DO YOU WANT TO DO IT?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, how do you think you would say, DO YOU WANT TO DO IT FOR ME?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we're not using the word FOR.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We don't need it in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: DO YOU WANT TO DO IT FOR ME?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The kitchen in Spanish is LA COCINA.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Or in most of Spain, LA COCINA.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You just make a verb from COCINA.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Actually, this is where we get CONCOCTION.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: CONCOCTION from, in English, WITH COOKING.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say, I COOK from COCINAR?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How do you say, HE COOKS or SHE COOKS or IT COOKS or USTED, YOU FORMAL COOK?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And with emphasis or clarification, if you want to use the word for YOU?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What if we wanted to use the word for THEY to emphasize or to clarify?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Or ELLAS, if it's a female group.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What if we wanted to say, YOU GUYS are COOKING, with the emphasis or the clarification?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And with the emphasis or the clarification?

text: How would you say I CAN?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How is I CAN related to POWER?

text: CAN YOU COOK SOMETHING FOR ME?

text: So what was the word for SOMETHING?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How do you think you're gonna say this in Spanish?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: CAN YOU COOK SOMETHING FOR ME?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: ME PUEDES COCINAR ALGO, PUEDES COCINARME ALGO?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say I HAVE COOKED?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we said that this tense of HAVE COOKED, I HAVE COOKED instead of I COOKED, we can use it more in Spanish than in English.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So for example, in English it sounds much more natural to say I COOKED at 6 o'clock.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But in Spanish it's not a problem to say I HAVE COOKED at 6 o'clock.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So at 6 o'clock is A LAS SEIS.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What you actually mean when you say A LAS SEIS is A LAS SEIS HORAS.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: A little bit like in English when you say at 1600 hours.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say I HAVE COOKED at 6 o'clock?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The word for 8 in Spanish is OCHO.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We have this similar root in octagon, you know a shape with 8 sides, or octopus which has 8 legs, or in October which, although now it's the 10th month in the Roman calendar, there were only 10 months, and October was month number 8.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say WE HAVE COOKED at 8 o'clock?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The word for 9 in Spanish is NUEVE.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We can see in November, which used to be the 9th month, that all splits into UE.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we have the same with 10.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: 10 is DIEZ, or DIEZ in most of Spain.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What does that sound like if we go back to our calendar?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: DECEMBER, which used to be the 10th month.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And of course, again, an example of splitting.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: QUEDAR in Spanish means to remain, or to be left over, and it actually has quite a few other meanings as well.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's quite a flexible verb, QUEDAR.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But for now, to remain, or to be left over.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And QU in Spanish is always a K sound.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You must resist any temptation to pronounce QUEDAR if you were to read this.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The word QUE, the word for what, that we learnt, is spelled Q-U-E.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So QU, this combination, is always a K.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So in Spanish, if you want to say I stay, actually you say I remain myself.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This is the way you say I stay in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we start with remain, which is QUEDAR.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how do you say I remain?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It doesn't split here, but good for trying.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You may have heard HASTA LA VISTA, until the view, literally until the seeing, until we see each other.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So now you can say, I'm staying here until 10 o'clock.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I'm staying here, I remain myself here.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's literally like LAS DIEZ HORAS, but you don't say HORAS.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Maybe historically people said it, but not anymore.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: ME QUEDO AQUÍ or ACÁ HASTA LAS DIEZ.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So if ME QUEDO, I remain myself, is I'm staying.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How do you think you would say we are staying?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Good, but now you have some vowel harmony popping in because we were concentrating on the other bit.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this mistake managed to come back.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You stay or you remain yourself, speaking informally.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you make it emphatic now?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Because this TE is not emphatic, it's not optional.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We have to put this ME in ME QUEDO to get the meaning of stay.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we have to put this TE in TE QUEDAS to get the meaning of stay.
